components.title: Welcome to the Melnik Group Website
components.html: Our research concerns with human, natural, and man-made systems, along with their interactions. Man-made systems include engineering systems, as well as context-dependent complex dynamic structures. Among others, examples of such structures may include social and financial systems and their networks. By developing tools and methods of mathematical modeling and by applying them along with two other research methodologies based on theory and experiment, we seek a better understanding of new phenomena and processes in studying complex dynamic systems which include coupled human-environment systems, as well as man-made systems. In most cases, our focus is on coupled multiscale phenomena and processes in such systems. Read More About Our Research

components.title: Coupled Multiscale Phenomena and Processes in Complex Dynamic Systems
components.html:
Some of the most important and challenging problems in scienceand engineering are coupled problems. The coupling ispronounced at three basic levels:
  • the level of systems coupling as it is the case inhuman-environment and human-centered systems, or at thelevel of field coupling as it is the case inthermo-elasticity and electro-elasticity, as well as inmany other areas of applications.
  • the level of coupled effects between different parts of the system, and/or
  • the level of coupling between differentspatial/spatio-temporal scales at which the natural, human, or man-made system, that is being studied, operates.
This coupling brings to life new phenomena, the phenomenawhich are not amenable to an adequate description with conventional mathematical models, traditionally developed without accounting for the coupled nature of the problem. At the M3AI® Lab, we focus on the development of coupled mathematical models for addressing fundamental questions of science and solving new problems in science and engineering. Our main interests lie with Complex Dynamic Systems, typically capable of information processing. We study coupled phenomena, effects, and processes in such systems that are becoming increasingly important in addressing key societal challenges of the 21st century and beyond. Read More About Our Research.

components.title: Head Profile
components.html: Roderick Melnik is a Full Professor at the Wilfrid Laurier University in Waterloo, Canada. It is the older of the two universities in the city of Waterloo. He is a Tier I Canada Research Chair in Mathematical Modelling. He has been also affiliated with two other nearby universities (Waterloo and Guelph) and the Centre for Applied Mathematics BCAM in Europe. Before joining Laurier, Professor Melnik held senior professorial and research positions in the USA, Europe, and Australia. He remains associated with Syddansk University in Denmark where he served as Head of Mathematical Modelling and Engineering Mathematics at the Mads Clausen Institute for a number of years. Later, he was a Full Professor in the Computational Analysis and Modelling Program at the Louisiana Tech University in the USA from where he moved to Canada in 2004. Dr Melnik has also experience in working as a scientist outside of academia. In the late 1990s, he held the position of senior mathematician at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Sydney, Australia, working in the Division of Mathematical and Information Sciences until he joined the Syddansk University in Denmark as full professor. Dr Melnik received his M.Sc. degree in Applied Mathematics and Ph.D. degree in Computational Mathematics from the Kiev State University in 1985 and 1989, respectively. Since 1989 Professor Melnik held academic tenures in Europe, Australia, and North America and has published extensively, as a sole author and with his collaborators from around the world, in the field of applied mathematics, computational sciences, and mathematical modelling in sciences and technology.

Professor Melnik's major results are in the development, analysis and applications of mathematical models in studying coupled dynamic phenomena, systems, and processes. His research contributions have significant impact on a number of areas in nanoscience, bio-nanotechnology, global environmental issues, networks, and more recently brain research, to name just a few. His interests include human, natural, and man-made systems, along with their interactions.

As an active researcher and academic, he is involved in numerous editorial duties and professional services in the applied mathematics, modelling, and a larger scientific community. He is an active member in major professional societies, including the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Society of Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Canadian Applied and Industrial Mathematics Society and its analogue in Australia ( ANZIAM ), and the New York Academy of Sciences. Since 1998 he is an Elected Fellow of the Institute of Mathematics and its Applications in the United Kingdom. Dr Melnik was the recipient of the Hans Christian Andersen Academy Fellowship Award in Denmark with only two such awards that were given annually to researchers worldwide. He was also a visiting fellow at the Isaac Newton Institute of the University of Cambridge in England, at the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications of the University of Minnesota in the USA, the Center of Excellence in Applied Mathematics in Spain, and other research institutions in Europe, North America, and Australia.

components.title: A Brief Research Overview and Link to Publications
components.html: The M3AI<sup>®</sup> Lab is the Laboratory for Mathematical Modelling, Algorithms, and Information-Processing Complex Dynamic Systems. All such systems are unified by the fact that they receive information from other systems and/or their sub-systems and, before transmitting it, they change that information in some manner. Such systems cover spatio-temporal scales from the vastness of the universe to planetary scales, and all the way to the smallest known scales. They require the development and applications of different mathematical models and algorithms. Among other intriguing aspects, within such systems, we are interested in coupled multiscale phenomena and processes.
Follow the link below to our publications or keep reading to learn more about some of our projects and research contributions.

We are a multidisciplinary group based at the M3AI<sup>®</sup> Lab, Waterloo, Canada. In addressing challenges of modern science, technology, and society, we deal with a range of cutting edge problems at the interface of mathematical and statistical sciences with such disciplines as physics and mechanics, nanoscience and nanotechnology, engineering and materials science, biological sciences and medicine, as well as cognitive social sciences.

Most of our research lie at the interface between a specific discipline or disciplines and mathematics, where the development and application of efficient mathematical modeling tools and techniques is a key to success. This requires addressing both fundamental and applied issues.

In our group, we focus on the development of mathematical models, algorithms, and computational techniques for studying complex dynamic systems. You can learn more about some of our projects by clicking at the corresponding link with keywords provided:

We deal with continuous and discrete models, stochastic and deterministic, depending on the problem at hand. Since systems and phenomena we study usually involve interactions of processes over a range of spatial and temporal scales, such problems are often multiscale in their nature. Many such problems are coupled problems and in the context of physical and engineering applications are often termed as multi-physics. The term 'coupled', however, is more generic as it is applied also to problems in bilogy, medicine, and other fields in science & engineering. Some of the models we deal with are non-local and therefore can be represented by integro-differential equations (e.g., problems involving collisions of many particles or interactions of many bodies provide typical examples), while others are essentially discrete models. Our interests include also non-equilibrium processes and systems far from their equilibrium. In a number of situations we have to take into account incompleteness of the information about the system or phenomenon we study which lead to stochastic models and probabilistic approaches. The models we deal with covers the spatial scales from nano to macro levels as well as a range of time scales.

In all the above projects, the solution of vast majority of problems is not amenable to analytical treatments and the development of efficient numerical methodologies and algorithms is required. Computational science and engineering relies on the development of mathematical modeling tools, and in this context our interests include also computational and mathematical physics, biological and life science applications, engineering mathematics, and cognitive social sciences. These context-specific applications enrich applied mathematics and the interface between these disciplines represent the core of of our research activities. Today, this interface encompasses some of the most challenging problems of modern science, technology, and society.

This trend will persist into the future, bringing exciting new opportunities for those researchers who are able to work in an interdisciplinary environment. Such opportunities exist in our group for those students and postdoctoral fellows who are keen on facing these challenges in their future careers for the benefit of our society. If you are a student, in particular a potential graduate student, or a researcher who is interested in working/collaborating with us on one of our current or emerging projects, please contact us.

components.title: Human Knowledge and Mathematical Modeling
components.html: Being a multidisciplinary group, for us, mathematical modeling is a universal tool of modern science and engineering, capable to handle efficiently global social challenges, a tool that is becoming increasingly indispensable in virtually all the areas of human endeavors. Mathematical models provide a ubiquitous framework for scientific progress, the development of new technologies, sustainable development of society, and the ever-expanding boundaries of human knowledge. They also serve as a natural safeguard against narrow specialization which, according to Einstein, is damaging to scientific progress and the true spirit of research.

“The area of scientific knowledge has been enormously extended, and theoretical knowledge has become vastly more profound in every department of science. But the assimilative power of the human intellect is and remains strictly limited. Hence it was inevitable that the activity of the individual investigator should be confined to a smaller and smaller section of human knowledge. Worse still, this specialization makes it increasingly difficult to keep even our general understanding of science as a whole, without which the true spirit of research is inevitably handicapped, in step with scientific progress.”

(Albert Einstein)

We believe that the true spirit of research and the key fundamentals in our general understanding of science as a whole as well as in our further progress in specific areas of science, engineering, and other areas of human endevour will increasingly rely on our progress in the field of mathematical modeling. At the M3AI® Lab, our view on the place of mathematical modeling in the dynamic process of expanding the boundaries of human knowledge is schematically presented below.

components.title: Multiscale Dynamic World - Research @ M3AI<sup>®</sup> Lab
components.html: Mathematical Modelling of Coupled Systems, Processes, and Phenomena

Many processes have components that interact in a complicated dynamic manner; they are "coupled." Certain materials, for example, can mimic biological systems by recovering their shapes after suffering an apparently permanent deformity. Understanding coupled processes has important implications for applications in such fields as medicine and biotechnology and many others as well. The problems that arise are intrinsically interdisciplinary and their solutions require the development of advanced mathematical tools. Such problems are rapidly becoming pervasive in our increasingly interconnected, multiscale dynamic world. They appear at different spatial scales, from the nanoscale to the global scale. Coupled systems, processes and phenomena are ubiquitous in physical and biological worlds, in engineering, environmental, and social sciences, business, finance, and economics. Their studies represent the cutting edge of modern research and they will be increasingly important for the future.

components.title: Courses and Student Supervision
components.html: Up-to-date materials for the courses I currently teach are given in the class and/or via university-approved Learning Environment Systems (e.g., MyLearning Space tools). Further information on the undergraduate courses I teach could be found in the <a href='https://students.wlu.ca/academics/calendars-and-policies/academic-calendars/index.html' target='_blank' >University Academic Calendar</a >. At the graduate level, I frequently teach MA680 (Mathematical Modelling for Science and Finance) and MA880 (Graduate Seminar in Mathematical and Statistical Modelling). Both of these courses have a modelling project component. Periodically, at the undergraduate level, I also supervise students in Directed Studies (MA485) and Honours Seminar (MA489), while at the graduate level in Special Topics (MA686) and Directed Studies (MA685). My current MA489 records provide the following information on research areas for this course: Mathematical modelling for complex systems, including natural, man-made, social, and financial; Machine learning / Deep learning algorithms in applications to such systems; Modelling of dynamic diseases, e.g. neurodegenerative, brain processes and brain models; Human intelligence, human errors, control systems, and models for knowledge creation.

For the information about research directions in my lab and the areas of applications we are working in, please explore our research pages. At the graduate level I supervise students in MA699 (Master's Thesis), MA695 (Major Graduate Project), as well as in MA899 (Doctoral Dissertation). Furthermore, I'm part of the graduate program in Applied Computing (MAC) and occasionally supervise students from that program as well. My current records provide the following information on research areas for the MAC program: Coupled multiscale phenomena, processes and systems; Machine learning / deep learning algorithms for biomedicine and materials science; human interactions with complex systems, including human-computer interactions, human intelligence and human errors.
If you are interested in research topics overlapping with the research directions of the M3AI® Lab, you are welcome to contact me, in particular if you are planning to continue your studies.
<font face='Monotype Corsiva' size='5' >Good luck with your studies! </font>

components.title: Teaching Portfolio with a few Words on my Teaching Philosophy

components.html: I have been very fortunate and honored to teach university students in Australia, Europe, and the United States, before coming to Canada in 2004. I taught around 60 different courses at the university level. They range from Data Analysis, Statistical Methods, and Stochastic Processes to Mathematical Modelling for Science and Finance Applications. I taught courses at all levels, from freshman to Ph.D., and some of them I taught to the students from different disciplines, including the students from engineering departments, as well as from sciences such as biology and psychology. Some additional information about my Teaching Portfolio can be found here. No doubt that I have learned a lot from my students, not only because 'to teach is to learn twice', but because each student brings to the class his or her own inspiration and energy, helping me to appreciate better words of Henry Ford who once said: 'Anyone who stops learning is old, whether at twenty or eighty; anyone who keeps learning stays young.' I do hope also that my students have learned a lot from me and what I do in the class is striving to pass a long-lasting interest to the subjects I teach to my students and demonstrating that 'the mind is not a vessel to be filled, but a fire to be ignited'. In this way, I put myself into a position to claim what once was claimed by Henry Adams: 'A teacher affects eternity; he can never tell where his influence stops'.

Teaching Pages by Prof. Roderick Melnik

Tell me and I forget Teach me and I remember Involve me and I learn.

(Benjamin Franklin)

seo.title: Prospective Students | M3AI® Lab & Melnik Research Group
seo.description: Thank you for your interest in working with us. We currently have student research positions available in our group. Interested candidates are invited to inquire more information, with a CV and a motivation letter attached.

components.html: Thank you for your interest in working with us. We currently have student research positions available in our group. Interested candidates are invited to inquire more information, with a CV and a motivation letter attached. The M3AI<sup>®</sup> Lab offers an excellent research and training environment, as well as support. Our student members present their research results at national and international meetings. They have been University's gold medal winners, as well as recipients of other prestigious awards and prizes.

Please note that I do not respond to mails sent to a list of professors. If you are interested in the research we do at the M3AI® Lab, you should note the following:
  1. All our research projects are interdisciplinary and you can learn more about what we do in the Research Overview section of this website. To be successful, you will have to have a genuine interest in working with the methods and tools of mathematical modelling in one or several Application Areas of our research.
  2. Strong motivated students, with internal drive for success and excellence in research, will be considered on a continuous basis in any of the Application Areas listed, regardless of our current research project priorities.
  3. Your attachments should be in pdf files. Files sent in Microsoft Office formats are given lower priority in consideration. Files sent in zip formats will likely be blocked by the University IT security services.

Finally, I'm not an administrator, I'm a researcher, so I will not be able to answer your possible questions related to administrative issues. Therefore, on such issues and general administrative questions about our graduate programs, including the PhD Program in Mathematical & Statistical Modelling, please write directly to the Graduate Coordinator. The answers to some FAQs can be found in the end of this page. Any research-related questions or inquiries are welcome and, provided you read and took into account the above notes, I am looking forward to hearing from you.

components.title: Information for prospective Masters and PhD students
components.html: Most projects in my group are interdisciplinary and involve problems that require strong working knowledge of mathematical and/or statistical modelling methods and tools and the ability to learn quickly from another discipline. Such disciplines could include physics, engineering, biology or neuroscience. As a doctoral student, who will be working in my group, you will have to register in the Interdisciplinary PhD Program in Mathematical & Statistical Modelling at Laurier. This is the preferred option, although another option exists with the University of Waterloo, where I'm an Adjunct Professor.

Myself (and possibly one of my colleagues from our graduate program or from UW) will be your supervisor/s. Information for prospective Master's students who would like to join my group are given in the end of this message. My main office is located at the Waterloo Campus of the Wilfrid Laurier University. You will be located in the M3AI<sup>®</sup> Lab which is part of the MS2Discovery Interdisciplinary Reserch Institute, based in Waterloo. Waterloo is a dynamic city in Ontario, 50 minutes west of Toronto, the major business and financial centre in Canada. All three Universities, Wilfrid Laurier University, University of Waterloo, and the University of Guelph are located within very close proximity to each other. Laurier is the oldest university on this region. These universities have joint library facilities via the TriUniversity Group of Libraries as well as joint computational facilities via the Sharcnet.

My group focuses on the studies of coupled dynamics and complex systems with methods & tools of mathematical modelling and computational experiments. If you plan to join my research group as a Doctoral student, your research project will be centered around one of the Application Areas of the M3AI® Lab. The current priority areas of the Lab are:
  • Mathematical Modelling in Neuroscience, Brain Research, and Bioengineering, focusing on dynamic coupled problems;
  • Development and Applications of Mathematical Models & Statistical Learning Algorithms in Energy, Environmental, and Biomedical Sectors;
  • Mathematical Modelling in Nanoscience and Bio-nanotechnologies, in particular in the analysis of phenomena that involve coupled effects and/or phase transitions, as well as in novel 'smart' materials that exhibit biological patterns of functioning.

Other areas are also possible, subject to student's background, experience, and matching with the Application Areas of the M3AI<sup>®</sup>. If you would like to work towards your PhD in one of the above areas, you have your Master's degree in Applied Mathematics or a relevant Science or Engineering discipline, you have strong analytical skills and programming experience, then you are most welcome to contact me to inquire further information. In your preliminary inquiry, we will be looking for indications that you have the necessary preparation to complete all PhD course requirements, you will be a productive team member, and you will likely make quick progress towards PhD.

I will also supervise from 1 to 3 Master's students who will be receiving support under my Canada Research Chair. To be eligible for stipends under the CRC Program, the students will have to register in the Graduate Studies at Laurier for the MSc program with the field of specialization in Mathematics for Science and Finance (or in the Master of Applied Computing Program). These MSc programs are normally completed in three or four consecutive terms, beginning in the Fall. In addition to the above listed research areas, the students may decide to specialize in the areas of
  • Inverse Problems and/or Stochastic Models (with possible applications in AI/Machine Learning or Financial Engineering, to name just a few)
  • Mathematical and Statistical Models in Neuroscience, focusing on neurodegenerative diseases and complex brain networks.

Preference will be given to students who decide to follow the thesis stream of the Master's program. The minimum admission requirements for these particular positions include an Honours degree in Applied Mathematics or another quantitative discipline such as Physics, Biophysics/Biosciences/Neuroscience, or Engineering. An aptitude for mathematical and computational tools, programming skills (e.g., Matlab, C++), as well as knowledge of theoretical and practical aspects of numerical linear algebra and differential equations are required. </br></br>The above information about opportunities for graduate studies in my group is directed to both Canadian and international students.

components.title: Opportunities for undergraduate students (Honours and vacation projects)
components.html: If you have completed 3rd or 4th year of your university studies and you have strong interest in the applications of mathematical and/or statistical models to problems from one or several of our Application Areas, you are welcome to discuss your interests further with Prof. Roderick Melnik

Students with strong background in applied quantitative disciplines, such as applied mathematics, physics, engineering, biophysics or neuroscience, who would like to continue their studies at the Master's or Doctoral level to work on one of the projects in my group are invited to explore more about our research and the areas of its applications.

Undergraduate and vacation students working in my group will be located on the Waterloo Campus at Laurier where there is a wealth of opportunities to be involved in research in an interdisciplinary setting.

Honours projects are open to the Laurier students only (mathematics students should register for MA489). Vacation projects may be open also to exceptional students from other Universities. Such projects provide an opportunity for students to complete a meaningful piece of research work in one of the areas of mathematical and/or statistical modelling and computational science, typically at the border between mathematics and another discipline.

Depending on a specific project, you should possess a subset of the following skills: an aptitude for mathematical and computational tools in science, technology, or finance; programming skills (Matlab, C++, Python, or similar); visualization programming skills; understanding of numerical methods; willingness to learn quickly from areas other than mathematics (e.g., physics and engineering, biology, financial engineering, neuroscience, depending on your interests).

As a result of your project, you will have the opportunity to develop your skills in the design, refinement and implementation of mathematical and/or statistical models, as well as the opportunity to familiarize yourself with tools and methodologies of computational experiments as they applied in science, technology, or other disciplines such as finance. You will produce a report describing the model, its analysis, algorithm development and results of your computational experiments whenever applicable. Where practical, the above projects may involve joint supervision with colleagues from other departments, e.g. biology, physics, kinesiology, psychology, or computer science departments.

The information on this page is mainly directed to the students from the Waterloo-Guelph and Greater Toronto area. If you are a student with strong credentials who lives elsewhere in Canada or abroad and you are interested in possible opportunities to work in my group, please consult section on Graduate Studies above.

faqs.title: Should I have some prior experience in a discipline area outside of mathematics before joining your group as a graduate student?
faqs.body: In my group, it is always considered to be an advantage, but not a pre-requisite. Today, all good science in general, and applied mathematics in particular, are intrinsically interdisciplinary. Your interest, enthusiasm, and the ability to learn quickly are the most important.

faqs.title: Will I receive funding for my graduate studies?
faqs.body: All MSc thesis and PhD students in my group receive funding through TAs, studentships, and RAs.

faqs.title: What are your expectations of graduate students in terms of their research outcome before they go for defence of their theses?
faqs.body: In terms of thesis content, a MSc thesis student - one conference paper, but the student should strive to make this into a journal paper as well. A PhD thesis is at least 3-4 full papers, minimum two of which are journal papers, in addition to workshop and conference presentations.

faqs.title: What is the duration of my graduate studies?
faqs.body: MSc students should expect to complete their degrees in 1 - 1.5 years, PhD students in 3-4 years.

faqs.title: Can I apply for my PhD studies after obtaining my BSc?
faqs.body: Unlike for some universities in the US, this is not typical for Canada, where we usually require a MSc degree or its equivalent. Students with a BSc would apply to the MSc program, and are encouraged to continue their work towards a PhD upon completion of the MSc.

faqs.title: Who is making admission decisions for your graduate programs?
faqs.body: They are made by the admissions committee. Please apply directly to the university and the department, strictly following the rules that are highlighted on the corresponding webpage. For example, for the Interdisciplinary PhD in Mathematical & Statistical Modelling, it can be found here: [link]. Without this, your application cannot be considered.

faqs.title: Do I need your permission to put your name as a potential supervisor on the admission form?
faqs.body: No, you do not. However, it is always a good idea to contact me in advance of your application.

faqs.title: I’m a graduate student, looking for a summer internship position. Could I apply for such a position in your lab?
faqs.body: If you are a registered student in one of the Canadian universities, in particular in Ontario, you are welcome to apply, provided you read carefully the notes at the beginning of this page. If you live outside Canada, I’m afraid I will not be able to accommodate your request.

faqs.title: Do you have openings at the postdoctoral level?
faqs.body: If you have recently finished your Ph.D. or will be finishing shortly, you are welcome to consult our page on Research Opportunities: [link].

It connects researchers working in mathematical and statistical modelling in various disciplines – from natural sciences and technology, finance, business and economics, and social sciences. MS2Discovery strives to create a dynamic and engaging environment conducive to interdisciplinary research, collaboration and communication.

components.title: Directions to Lab
components.html: We are located on the third floor of the Laurier Science Research Center. The University is the older of the two Universities in the city of Waterloo. In fact, it is the oldest university in this region of Ontario that includes the Tri-Cities (Cambridge, Kitchener and Waterloo) and the “Royal City” of Guelph. In addition to its main campus in Waterloo, Laurier has several other campuses, with its growing presence in Milton located along the Toronto-Waterloo Innovation Corridor.

The University Library belongs to the TriUniversity Group of Libraries which unites library resources at the Wilfrid Laurier University, the University of Guelph, and the University of Waterloo. The Waterloo region is one of the fastest growing communities in Canada, with a population of over half a million people. It is located in the beautiful part of the Southwestern Ontario, a short driving distance from the western edge of the Greenbelt of Toronto, the largest city in Canada.
Parking detail of the campus of Laurier in Waterloo can be found here. After parking your car, follow to the Science Research Centre where we are located in SR-316.
Directions to the Laurier Waterloo main Campus can be found here. The main Campus is also served by public transportation.

NOTE 1
The AI concept is linked to humans through the algorithm development, and a better way to use this concept is to call it the Artificial Human Intelligence (AHI). As such, the AHI is subject to human errors. During their evolution, humans have been using both organic and inorganic worlds to serve them better. In this sense, the idea of “artificial intelligence” is no different. A well-known example where the word “intelligence” has been built-in in the definition of the modern concepts includes “intelligent materials” due to their intrinsic properties of innate nature to adapt and/or react to external stimuli. Moreover, developing this concept further, some materials are attributed properties of “smartness” when they “learn” how to adapt and/or change in response to external stimuli. From “hardware”, the concepts of “intelligence” and “smartness” have been moved to “software”. What is lacking in this picture is one fundamental detail. It is the integration of human factor (and hence, human errors) in the process of development of AI and in the corresponding mathematical models. In one of our projects, we made the first steps in this direction on an example of engineering applications of AI.

NOTE 2
While the name of our lab carries the AI abbreviation, we associate it with algorithms for information (processing systems). It is the Laboratory for Mathematical Modelling, Algorithms, and Information-Processing Complex Dynamic Systems.

NOTE 3

In the analysis of brain-mind relationships and associated neuroscientific problems, among other things, we are interested in a mathematical description of the dynamics of thoughts and emotions. As part of this project, together with our European colleagues we have been studying the mechanisms of self-organized criticality in social processes of knowledge creation.

components.title: The AMMCS Conferences and the Kolmogorov-Wiener Prize
AMMCS Framework
components.html:
The establishment of the MS2Discovery Interdisciplinary Research Institute at goes back to 2004 when the Centre for Coupled Dynamics and Complex Systems was originated, informally combining WLU scientists from the Department of Mathematics, Biology, Chemistry, Physics and Computer Science. In the same year, a new interdisciplinary seminar series was established. These activities combined three major research areas in their broadest sense,

  • Applied Mathematics (AM),
  • Modelling (M), and
  • Computational Science (CS),

resulting in the abbreviation known now to a larger scientific and engineering community as AMMCS.

In 2011, when the WLU celebrated its the 100-th anniversary, its Waterloo Campus became the venue for a major international event in Applied Mathematics Modeling and Computational Science, the AMMCS-2011 Conference. Wilfrid Laurier University is the oldest university in the Cambridge-Kitchener-Waterloo-Guelph area, a beautiful part of Southwestern Ontario located in a comfortable driving distance from some of North America’s major tourist destinations, including the Niagara Escarpment, a UNESCO World Biosphere Reserve, Toronto and Niagara Falls.

The AMMCS-2011 conference had an exciting scientiﬁc program featuring nearly 50 special and contributed sessions in several parallel tracks, as well as 10 one-hour talks given by distinguished scientists and mathematicians. Each day of the conference, the scientiﬁc program started with a plenary session that featured one of the conference plenary speakers. The scientiﬁc program of the conference provided a unique opportunity for in-depth technical discussions and exchange of ideas in applied mathematics, computational science and mathematical modeling with their applications in natural and social sciences, engineering and technology, industry and ﬁnance. In 2014 AMMCS activities found their natural continuation in officially launching the MS2Discovery Interdisciplinary Research Institute. Further information about the Institute can be found here.
The AMMCS Kolmogorov-Wiener Prize was established in 2011 at the AMMCS-2011 meeting. It is awarded biannually at AMMCS international meetings.

components.title: The Kolmogorov-Wiener Prize for Young Researchers

components.html: 'Mankind has always seemed to me as a set of wandering in the fog lights that feel the shine, dissipated by the others, quite vaguely. But these lights are connected in a network of shiny filaments, each in one, two, three ... directions. And the occurrence of such breaks through the fog to the other light can quite reasonably be called a 'miracle.' (Andrey Kolmogorov)
'What most experimenters take for granted before they begin their experiments is infinitely more interesting than any results to which their experiments lead.' (Norbert Wiener)

Objectives:
The award is to recognize and support innovative interdisciplinary research carried out by researchers at an early stage of their career in the areas of mathematical, natural and applied sciences where methods and tools of mathematical modeling are decisive. Among other areas, it includes also systems science, computational science & engineering, as well as mathematical modeling in such areas as economics and finance, social, medical and life sciences.

Eligibility:
This is an award for young researchers in the category of recent PhD graduates and postdoctoral fellows under the age of 35. The eligibility criteria include young researchers who
  • (a) have earned their PhD degrees within 5 years of January 1 of the year of the award;
  • (b) have at least two peer refereed publications, minimum one of which has appeared in an internationally recognized journal;
  • (c) have presented their talks at an AMMCS event in the year of the award.

Nominations:
Nominations for this award from established researchers are welcome. Nominators should include (in a single pdf file):
  • (a) name and affiliation of nominee
  • (b) a brief statement describing the nominee's accomplishments (limited to 1-2 pages)
  • (c) list of main publications of the nominee relevant to the award
  • (d) name and affiliation of nominator

Frequency:
The prize is awarded biannually at AMMCS meetings.

Application:
The competition is based on a paper submitted to the selection committee - it should be a new unpublished manuscript intended for original publication in one of AMMCS-approved publication media, and therefore complying with the requirements of such a publication. Applications should include:
  • (a) the manuscript, as described above, in pdf format;
  • (b) detailed CV with academic record and list of publications plus one selected journal publication in pdf format;
  • (c) a summary of research work and accomplishments to date (limited to one page);
  • (d) a maximum of two letters of support are highly desirable, but not required;
  • (e) if the manuscript in Item (a) is co-authored, a statement from other authors that the candidate made a major and decisive contribution to the paper;
  • (f) a statement from the candidate that the paper has not been submitted for any other scientific awards.

Submissions and all accompanied materials must be in English. Your complete application package (in one single zipped file) should be sent with subject line 'AMMCS Kolmogorov-Wiener Young Researcher Award'.

Deadline:
Applications can be submitted immediately after receiving a notification of abstract acceptance (decisions are communicated to all corresponding authors), but not later than the deadline specified at the website of the AMMCS meeting held in the year of your application.

The winner is selected by the KW AMMCS Committee and the announcement of the winner will take place at the AMMCS meeting.

components.html: The main rationale behind these activities was derived from the fact that some of the most challenging problems in science and engineering require dealing with several different physical fields, the interaction of different parts of the system, and the interactions of various length and time scales, which may or may not be known a priori. Most such problems require mathematical modeling approaches for their solution. As many areas of science and engineering were conventionally divided in the past, these problems were difficult to address. With the development of new mathematical modeling techniques, such as those based on multifield, multiscale approaches, the situation is rapidly changing and we are now in a position to meet such challenges. Therefore, during 5 years of this project, which was run based on Ingenta technology, the editorial team handled contributions in all aspects of this development directed toward the study of coupled dynamic systems, phenomena, and processes, both deterministic and stochastic. This included model developments for coupled dynamic problems, their applications, fundamental mathematical problems in advancing the theory of coupled dynamic systems, as well as the development of new numerical procedures, high performance computing, and algorithmic aspects related to solving such problems.

components.title: Mathematics and Life Sciences
components.html: Prof. Roderick Melnik was one of the foundational members of the editorial board of the De Gruyter Series in Mathematics and Life Sciences. He served on the board for the period of 2013 - 2017. This series is devoted to the publication of monographs in the field. They cover topics and methods in fields of current interest that use mathematical approaches to understand and explain, model and influence phenomena in all areas of life sciences. This includes, among others, theory and application of biological mathematical modeling, complex systems biology, bioinformatics, computational biomodeling stochastic modeling, biostatistics, computational evolutionary biology, comparative genomics, or structural bioinformatics. The series also covers new types of mathematical problems that arise from biological knowledge. With contributions on the borderline of mathematics and life sciences, stimulating further research at the crossroads of these areas, the main objectives of the series has been to make such expositions available to and accessible by an interdisciplinary, growing readership hailing from all disciplines involved.

This emerging multidisciplinary field includes applications and advancements of these tools in all of the disciplines facing the challenges associated with the nanoscale systems. This includes, but not limited to, physics, chemistry, biology, materials science, medicine, and engineering. The project was carried out with De Gruyter. Centre for Complex Systems
components.html: The Centre for Coupled Dynamics & Complex Systems (CDCS) was a research unit from where the <a href='https://researchcentres.wlu.ca/ms2discovery-interdisciplinary-research-institute/' target='_blank' >MS2Discovery Institute</a > was developed. The centre was created in 2004 by the efforts of researchers from different departments of the Faculty of Science, combining research expertise in the areas of applied mathematics, physics, chemistry, and biology via tools and methods of mathematical modelling and computational science. Research activities of the CDCS centre focused on the following areas:

Mathematical models for coupled systems and phenomena; Computational physics, optoelectronics, and computational chemistry; Modelling in systems biology, computational genomics; Mathematical models for applications in nanoscience and bionanotechnology; Stochastic processes in sciences, engineering, and quantitative finance.

The backbone of the CDCS centre was the Laurier dynamic research community in mathematical & statistical modelling and computational science. Members of the centre together with their colleagues from other disciplines run several highly successful seminar series. They were active in establishing and maintaining links with colleagues from other institutions, inside and outside of Canada, as well as with industrial companies. At the CDCS Centre, both analytical and numerical methods were developed for solving challenging problems that appear at the cutting edge of scientific and technological applications. Over a decade, the CDCS researchers sponsored many undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and visitors. These traditions have been continued by the <a href='https://researchcentres.wlu.ca/ms2discovery-interdisciplinary-research-institute/' target='_blank' >MS2Discovery Interdisciplinary Research Institute</a >.

The main goal of the Centre for Coupled Dynamics & Complex Systems was to use the methodology of mathematical modelling and computational experiment and to develop new theories and techniques for the solution of important problems arising in sciences. Many such problems require dealing with processes and phenomena that have components interacting in a complicated manner; they are "coupled". Better understanding such processes and phenomena has important implications for applications in such diverse fields as optoelectronics, medicine, biotechnology, and finance, environmental and energy-saving technologies, among many others.

components.title: CSASM Interdisciplinary Seminar Series
components.html: As an interdisciplinary seminar series, CSASM was founded in 2004. It quickly became one of the major interdisciplinary activities at the university, known as the Laurier Seminar Series in Computational Science and Applied & Statistical Modelling (CSASM).  The series covered all areas of applied mathematics, computational physics, chemistry, and biology; mathematical, statistical, and computational models and tools as applied in natural and social sciences, engineering, business and economics, the areas where a substantial progress could be achieved due to Computational Science and Applied & Statistical Modelling.

The Laurier CSASM was a forum for academics, students, business and industry professionals to exchange ideas in order to facilitate interdisciplinary collaboration in the areas of computational science and applied & statistical modelling, and to help train high quality and employable students. The series was founded by   Prof. Ilias Kotsireas  and Prof. Roderick Melnik who were this series’ main organizers and coordinators. The seminar series, that was run from 2004 till 2014, became an important networking activity in Ontario in the field of computational science and modelling. In 2014 the activities carried out by the Centre for Coupled Dynamics & Complex Systems and CSASM were passed to the newly created MS2Discovery Interdisciplinary Research Institute.
CSASM attracted funding from various sponsors, including SHARCNET, STEP, the Special Initiative fund, and many others.

Within the CSASM framework, some seminars were held in collaboration with and at the <a href='http://www.perimeterinstitute.ca/' target='_blank' >Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics</a > (Laurier-Perimeter Seminar Series).

A reasonably complete list of visitors with abstracts of their talks can be found <a href='/links/research/ms2discovery_2014_calendar.pdf' target='_blank' >here</a >. For one of the promotional brochures of this seminar series follow this <a href='/links/research/ms2discovery_brochure.pdf' target='_blank' >link</a >.
